files.description: Implements a deterministic-run policy that sets and validates fixed RNG seeds across Python/random, NumPy, and any supported frameworks and provides context managers to enforce determinism during benchmark runs.
Provides stable JSON serialization utilities (canonical key ordering, normalized floats, consistent indentation/newlines) to ensure byte-for-byte reproducible output files across machines and CI.
Implements a numeric-tolerance comparison engine for expected-vs-actual JSON that supports absolute/relative tolerances, per-path overrides, NaN/inf handling, and produces a structured diff report.

Integrates deterministic policy, stable serialization, and tolerance-based numeric diffs into the existing expected-vs-actual comparison against expected/benchmark_case_001.expected.json and returns CI-friendly exit codes and reports.
End-to-end runner script that executes benchmark_case_001 with fixed seed/settings, writes canonicalized actual output, and invokes the integrated comparator against the expected JSON.
Defines the single source of truth for RNG seeds, serialization options, and numeric tolerance thresholds (including optional per-field overrides) used locally and in CI.
CI workflow that runs the benchmark runner with the shared determinism/tolerance config, uploads diff artifacts on failure, and ensures consistent settings across CI environments.
Unit tests covering tolerance comparisons (abs/rel), stable ordering, NaN/inf rules, and representative expected-vs-actual JSON diffs to prevent regressions in the harness.

missionDescription: Add a deterministic-run policy and numeric tolerance harness integrated with the existing expected-vs-actual comparison: enforce fixed RNG seeds, stable serialization ordering, and tolerance-based numeric diffs when comparing outputs to `expected/benchmark_case_001.expected.json`; ensure CI uses the same settings.
missionSuccessCriteria: Complete strategic task identified by Meta-Coordinator or escalated by Strategic Tracker
Even after syntax fixes, expected-vs-actual matching will be unstable without determinism/tolerance rules; this directly addresses the pipeline stability needed for CI to pass consistently.
